I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up to $20,000,000 in tenge equivalent to RG Brands Kazakhstan LLP for the Inclusive Beverage 
Production and Distribution Project. 
 
2. 
The  project  will  support  the  expansion  of  the  RG  Brands  Group  (RGB)  across  the 
beverage value chain through the financing of (i) energy efficient coolers for retail distribution in 
Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic and (ii) production equipment in Kazakhstan. The project 
will support the diversification of the Kazakhstan economy by enhancing non-oil exports and will 
improve the livelihoods of shopkeepers and support women’s empowerment in both countries. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT    

 
A. 
 

Project Identification and Description 

1. 

Project Identification 

 
3. 
Kazakhstan’s middle-income country challenge. From 2010 to 2018, gross domestic 
product (GDP) grew at an average annual rate of 4.5%, reaching $9,331 in 2018; and the share 
of the population living below the national poverty line fell from 6.5% to 2.5%.1 However, the global 
financial  crisis  of  2007–2008  and  the  tenge  devaluations  of  2014–2015  considerably  reduced 
economic  growth;  and  Kazakhstan  continues  to  need  to  diversify  its  economy  from  natural 
resources,  which  still  accounted  for  16%  of  gross  domestic  product  (footnote  1)  and  90%  of 
exports in 2017.2 To diversify and transcend its middle-income country challenges, productivity 
and  competitiveness  need  to  increase  in  the  non-oil  private  sector,  supported  by  appropriate 
investment, capacity building and innovation.3 
 
Kazakhstan’s underdeveloped food and agriculture sector. Agriculture represents 4% 
4. 
of Kazakhstan’s GDP (footnote 1) and 6% of exports (footnote 2). Local agricultural products are 
generally less competitive than imported products, due to lower productivity and quality. Further, 
capacity  utilization  in  the  food  industry  remains  low  due  to  obsolescence  and  physical 
deterioration of fixed assets. Food safety systems are underdeveloped, and agricultural exports 
continue to be plagued by a lack of logistics, imperfections in legislations and insufficient efforts 
for brand promotion.4 
 
The Kyrgyz Republic’s development priorities. The Kyrgyz Republic is a lower-middle 
5. 
income country, with GDP per capita at the lower end of Central Asian countries ($1,281 in 2018). 
Poverty remains high at 26% in 2017, based on the national poverty line, and uneven across the 
country  (74%  of  the  poor  live  in  rural  areas).  The  Kyrgyz  Republic  critically  needs  to  create 
employment and livelihoods opportunities in all productive sectors. As the country is a small and 
landlocked economy, regional cooperation and integration is also a national imperative.5  
 
6. 
Regional integration in Central Asia. As part of the Eurasian Economic Union (EEU), 
all markets in the union, including Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic, come under common

7. 
Borrower’s  selection.  RGB  is  a  leading  food  and  beverage  group  in  Kazakhstan, 
producing milk, tea, juice, water, and other packaged beverages. ADB had provided a loan to the 
group in 2013.6 Given ADB’s long-term relationship with RGB, ADB was approached for financing 
another round of expansion [Redacted]. ADB again assessed the financing needs of the company 
and  found  it  to  be  suitable  given  its  continued  solid  operational  and  financial  track  record. 
[Redacted] 
 

2. 

Project design 

 
8. 
The  project  consists  of  (i)  the  expansion  and  strengthening  of  RGB’s  distribution 
infrastructure,  (ii)  the  expansion  and  upgrading  of  production  lines  for  beverages,  (ii)  working 
capital for beverage production and distribution, and (iv) potential acquisitions that would further 
boost  RGB’s  and  shopkeeper’s  sales.  The  project  is  central  to  RGB’s  strategy  of  improving 
production and distribution efficiency and maintaining and expanding direct access to customers 
in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic. [Redacted] 
 
9. 
Energy  efficiency  and  inclusive  distribution.  The  project  will  help  expand  and 
strengthen  RGB’s  distribution  infrastructure  across  Kazakhstan  and  the  Kyrgyz  Republic.  The 
funds will be invested in energy efficient coolers (which will reduce annual emission of CO2) that 
will be deployed in small convenience stores, of which at least 50% owned by women. [Redacted] 
Given  the  large  territory  of  Kazakhstan,  efficient  distribution  is  critical.  RGB  works  with  about 
44,000 small convenience stores, including more than half in rural areas. These stores are often 
owned and run by families that lack the financial resources to buy their own equipment. RGB will 
also place coolers in the Kyrgyz Republic. This will reduce concentration risk for RGB and improve 
non-farm livelihoods for small shopkeepers in the Kyrgyz Republic. 
 
Resource efficient beverage production. The investment will include a new bottling line 
10. 
for flavored water and other beverages and the upgrading of existing juice and water bottling lines, 
to  increase  production  efficiency,  notably  through  reduced  usage  of  both  energy  and  plastics, 
used  in  bottles  and  caps.  The  project  will  also  support  modernization  across  RGB’s  existing 
production facilities, to improve cost and energy efficiency, as well as partly finance the company’s 
incremental working capital requirements. 
 
11. 
Corporate governance technical assistance (TA). As a complement to the project, ADB 
will  provide  TA  to  RGB  to  enhance  its  corporate  governance,  including  through  deeper 
engagement with stakeholders in the beverage value chain.7 The TA will help RGB strengthen 
corporate policies. The TA will support an inclusive business approach for RGB’s engagement 
with shopkeepers, with the implementation of a monitoring mechanism to track the gender and 
income of the shopkeepers and trainings for women shop owners on financial literacy and digital 
technology.  The  TA  will  help  RGB  engage  with  local  and  central  governments  to  improve  the

17. 
Impacts. The project is aligned with the fifth target of sustainable development goal (SDG) 
5 (gender equality): “ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for 
leadership at all levels of decision making in political, economic and public life”. The project will 
also contribute the second target of SDG 8 (decent work and economic growth): “achieve higher 
levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, 
including through a focus on high-value added and labor-intensive sectors”.9 
 
Outcome.  The  project’s  outcome  is  inclusive  production  and  distribution  of  quality 
18. 
beverages  promoted.  At  least  7,000  additional  shopkeepers  will  benefit  from  cooler-generated 
sales in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic. Further, RBG will create at least 138 jobs (including 
125 for women) in Kazakhstan.

C. 
 
20. 
Consistency  with  ADB  strategy  and  country  strategy.  The  project  is  aligned  with 
ADB’s Strategy 2030, which calls for ADB: (i) “to scale up its financing for agribusiness”; (ii) to 
“promote  commercial  sustainability  through  high  standards  of  corporate  governance,  integrity, 
transparency, and environmental and social safeguards”, and (iii) to promote gender equality in 
at least 75% of the number of ADB’s committed operations by 2030.10 The project is also aligned 
with  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategies,  for  Kazakhstan  (2017–2021)  and  for  the  Kyrgyz 
Republic  (2018–2022). 11  The  country  strategy  for  Kazakhstan  identifies  strengthening  the 
foundations for economic diversification through private sector development as a key operational 
priority.  The  strategy  also  emphasizes  the  role  that  ADB  can  play  to  contribute  to  inclusive 
development and reducing spatial and gender inequalities. The project is also aligned with the 
country strategy for the Kyrgyz Republic, which identifies the strengthening of agricultural value 
chains and promotion of regional integration and cooperation as key focus areas. 
 
21. 
Consistency  with  sector  strategy  and  relevant  ADB  operations.  The  project  is 
consistent with Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 5 (Promoting Rural Development and 
Food Security, 2019–2024) as the plan emphasizes the importance of “local value addition for 
both  domestic  and  export  markets”  and  “opportunities  to  make  an  impact  in  the  fast-growing 
branded food, modern retail, and e-commerce sectors”. The project is also aligned with Strategy 
2030  Operational  Plan  for  Priority  7  of  Strategy  2030:  (Fostering  Regional  Cooperation  and 
Integration), which makes the development of regional trade a strategic priority.12 The project is 
also consistent with ADB’s sovereign operations in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic, notably 
the  ongoing  TA  by  ADB’s  Central  and  West  Asia  Department  to  support  the  development  of 
agricultural wholesale markets in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic, within the Almaty-Bishkek 
Economic Corridor framework.13

Unique Features 

G. 
 
22. 
The project is ADB’s first regional agribusiness project in Central Asia. RGB will contribute 
to providing livelihoods to small retailers Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic by enabling them 
to participate in the high-quality beverage value chain. RGB has also committed to a gender action 
plan which aims to increase women’s empowerment across the beverage value chain (para. 41). 
Finally, an innovative approach to corporate  governance TA will help promote new models for 
inclusive business, circular economy, and responsible consumption (para. 11).

Safeguards and Social Dimensions 

 
A. 
 
25. 
ADB  has  categorized  the  investment  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009) as follows: environment (category C), involuntary resettlement (category C) and

26. 
ADB has undertaken due diligence and reviewed the potential environmental and social 
impacts of the project and  the measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for the 
adverse impacts in the safeguard reports and plans. The environmental and social measures and 
the  institutional  capacity  and  commitment  of  RGB  to  manage  the  project’s  social  and 
environmental impacts are deemed adequate. 
 
RGB has implemented a corporate wide Environmental and Social Management System 
27. 
(ESMS)  per  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (SPS)  since  2013.  The  two  bottling  plants

 Based on the due diligence conducted, the key anticipated impacts on the environment 
28. 
are  related  to  potential  greenhouse  gas  release  from  replaced  cooling  units  and  waste 
management.  [Redacted]  The  project  will  also  have  an  indirect  impact  related  to  increased 
production of containers for beverage products, leading to increased generation of solid waste. 
To mitigate this impact, the project will introduce technology that will reduce the usage of plastic 
for bottles and caps. In addition, ADB’s TA will assist RGB in the identification of opportunities to 
further  reduce  the  usage  of  plastics  and  improve  recycling  mechanisms,  in  coordination  with 
public sector stakeholders. The project will also enhance the energy efficiency of production lines 
and introduce more energy efficient coolers. The project may also have an indirect impact related 
to increased production of sugar sweetened drinks, leading to health impacts. This impact will be 
mitigated by the increase in demand for low- or no-sugar drinks (including many of RGB products 
such as water and flavored water) and ADB’s TA will assist RGB in the development of awareness 
campaign  on  the  impacts  of  unhealthy  diets  and  excessive  sugar  consumption.  Finally,  gaps 
regarding corporate policies will also be addressed by a gender action plan (para. 41) and through 
ADB’s TA (para. 11).
